fields.name: Python: Basic Syntax and Variables
fields.description: Learn the essentials of Python programming, including variables, data types, syntax, and naming rules.
fields.text:
Welcome to 'Python: Basic Syntax and Variables'!

This course is your first step into Python programming. You will learn the core concepts that form the foundation of every Python program. These include how to declare variables, work with different data types, follow correct naming rules, and write syntactically correct Python code.

Each module in this course is designed to guide you with clear explanations, examples, and practice missions. By the end of this course, you will be able to write simple yet correct Python code confidently.

fields.name: Python Developer
fields.description: A complete path to becoming a Python developer.

fields.description: Learn how to build web applications using Django and Python.

fields.description: Understand the basics of version control using Git.

fields.description: Explore essential algorithms and data structures for problem-solving.

fields.name: Variables and Basic Syntax
fields.description: Learn how to declare variables and understand Python's syntax.
fields.text:
Variables and Basic Syntax

In Python, a variable is a name that stores data. You can think of it as a label attached to a value.

Declaring a variable is simple:
x = 5

This creates a variable called x and assigns it the value 5. Python automatically understands the type of data.

Remember, Python uses an easy-to-read syntax, but the order of elements is important. For example, always put the variable on the left side and the value on the right side of the = sign.

fields.name: Working with Text and Numbers
fields.description: Explore how to use text (strings) and numbers in Python.
fields.text:
Working with Text and Numbers

Python allows variables to hold different types of data:
- Integers (int): Whole numbers like 7
- Floats (float): Numbers with decimal points like 3.14
- Strings (str): Text data like 'Hello'

You can store and manipulate these types easily:
age = 30
name = 'Alice'

Strings must always be enclosed in single ' or double " quotes.

fields.name: Data Types and Booleans
fields.description: Learn the key data types in Python, including booleans.
fields.text:
Data Types and Booleans

Python has several important data types:
- int: Whole numbers (7)
- float: Decimal numbers (19.99)
- str: Text ('Hello')
- bool: Boolean values (True, False)

Booleans are used to represent truth values and are extremely useful for controlling program flow.

Example:
is_active = True
price = 19.99

Always assign the correct data type to your variable depending on the context.

fields.name: Variable Naming Rules
fields.description: Understand the rules for writing valid Python variable names.
fields.text:
Variable Naming Rules

Python has specific rules for naming variables:
- Must start with a letter (a-z, A-Z) or an underscore _
- Cannot start with a number
- Cannot contain spaces or special characters like - or @
- Cannot be a reserved keyword (like for, if, class)

Examples of valid names:
my_var, _hidden_value

Examples of invalid names:
1value, my-var, for

Following these rules helps avoid errors and makes your code more readable.

fields.name: Writing Valid Python Code
fields.description: Master writing correct Python syntax.
fields.text:
Writing Valid Python Code

Python code must follow its strict syntax rules to run successfully:
- Assignment: Always have the variable on the left, the = sign in the middle, and the value on the right.
x = 2 + 3

- Indentation: Python uses indentation (spaces) to define blocks of code. Always indent your code correctly.
- Statements must be complete: Don't forget colons, parentheses, or correct spelling.

Example of invalid code:
2 + 3 = result  # Invalid, cannot assign to an expression

Always double-check your code for these common mistakes before running it.
